sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Using the Newton-Raphson method, find the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5 accurate to 4 decimal places. Start the iteration with an initial guess of x0 = 2.
message_2:
To use the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5. The derivative f'(x) = 3x^2 - 2.

The Newton-Raphson formula is: x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)

We start with an initial guess of x0 = 2. We will iterate the process until the difference between consecutive approximations is less than 0.0001 (to ensure accuracy up to 4 decimal places).

Iteration 1:
x0 = 2
f(x0) = 2^3 - 2*2 - 5 = 8 - 4 - 5 = -1
f'(x0) = 3*(2^2) - 2 = 12 - 2 = 10
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) = 2 - (-1) / 10 = 2 + 0.1 = 2.1

Iteration 2:
x0 = 2.1
f(x0) = (2.1)^3 - 2*2.1 - 5 ≈ -0.289
f'(x0) ≈ 3*(2.1)^2 - 2 ≈ 12.93
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) ≈ 2.1 - (-0.289) / 12.93 ≈ 2.1223

Iteration 3:
x0 = 2.1223
f(x0) ≈ (2.1223)^3 - 2*2.1223 - 5 ≈ -0.0206
f'(x0) ≈ 3*(2.1223)^2 - 2 ≈ 13.4946
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) ≈ 2.1223 - (-0.0206) / 13.4946 ≈ 2.1235

Iteration 4:
x0 = 2.1235
f(x0) ≈ (2.1235)^3 - 2*2.1235 - 5 ≈ -0.0015
f'(x0) ≈ 3*(2.1235)^2 - 2 ≈ 13.5238
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) ≈ 2.1235 - (-0.0015) / 13.5238 ≈ 2.1236

The difference between the last two approximations is less than 0.0001, so we can stop here. The root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5, accurate to 4 decimal places, is approximately x ≈ 2.1236.
